prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the AITA post is in the wrong for ending free rides for their friend. The situation is that the friend has been riding in their car hundreds of times without contributing to gas, but this one time, the author forgot their purse at home, so the friend put $10 in gas. Then the author says the friend should find their own way around now.

First, I need to assess the context. The friend has been getting free rides consistently, which the author has been covering all the gas costs. The friend only contributed once when the author forgot their purse. The author then ends the arrangement, asking the friend to find their own way. 

Is the author in the wrong? Well, the friend wasn't contributing anything before, so the author is choosing to no longer subsidize the rides. The friend's one-time contribution of $10 doesn't seem like a pattern of helping. The author's request is about fairness—expecting some contribution or responsibility from the friend. 

In many situations, people might expect some reciprocity when sharing resources like gas. If the friend hasn't contributed before, the author is within their rights to set boundaries. The friend might see this as unfair, but the author isn't obligated to keep covering all costs. 

So, the answer would be B (No, the author isn't in the wrong). They're setting a boundary after a pattern of one-sided benefit. The friend's single act of giving gas doesn't negate the prior behavior. The author has the right to decide who they give rides to and under what conditions.
